I figured it would be a good idea to start slowly, so I went to a temp agency. I was ushered into a small room and given directions on a proofreading test that stumped me for 10 minutes. Unfortunately, the entire exam was supposed to take 20.

They told me they would call me. After wandering around for a while in a daze, I happened to see the young woman who interviewed me. With an amused look on her face, she began placing some papers in a machine that made a shredding sound.
Martin Obolsky

The scene is the town pool in Glen Rock at about 3 p.m., and private swim lessons are in full swing. One mother sitting poolside and observing the lessons -- in addition to the toned and tanned male instructor -- calls to another mother a few yards away.
''Come sit by me, the view is quite nice,'' she calls.
''I know,'' responds the other. ''I'm paying for that view.''
Ah, the perks of private swim lessons.
Deirdre Flanagan Ward
NO FORD IN MY FUTURE
That Ford makes more intimidating versions
Of S.U.V. each year is evident:
Explorer Expedition now Excursion
Towering over my Expedient.
Bob McKenty
One car poem deserves another one -- in this case untitled:
My shining new car is expensive and nifty.
It cost what my house did in 1950.
BARBARA ALPREN

I recently put a new ''Welcome Friends'' mat on my front porch. That night, I heard someone at the door. When I investigated, I discovered a wild turkey beating his head against the storm door, his wife and chick waiting expectantly under my dining room window.
Dorothy Ryan
A different take on the endless, spendless days of summer.
Cost of admission for one adult and four children to the Metropolitan Museum of Art: $10.
Lunch at Ruby Foo's, including garage parking: $85.
The opportunity to cross the bridge and expose my four sons to a day of culture rather than a day of chlorine: priceless.
Deirdre Flanagan Ward
The week of my daughter's high school graduation, she received a letter from a town near Princeton Junction, which is where we live, though we couldn't identify the name on the envelop.
It was a letter from a little girl describing her family, among other things. We thought it was the school's idea to get her to be the big sister to a girl from the next town.

It took a while for my daughter to realize the little girl was herself, and it was an assignment from Madeline Crass's second-grade class. Ms. Crass had kept the letters and mailed them to her students upon their graduation.
My daughter wrote her back that it was by far the best graduation gift she could have asked for.
Joseph Sun
